System - System control

Created:2018-03-04  Last modified:2019-02-12

  • Introduction
  • Experiences

  1. Introduction

    Concepts

    • Dependency (usa-a): a particular function object A (e.g. Printer) is given to one of the method of an object B. B only use A inside the its method, and B does not have a property that always hold A.
    • Association/Aggregation: all object are created outside other objects, each object has its own lifecycle. Each object can have multiple other objects' references. Each object can be referenced by multiple objects.
    • Composition (has-a): A master object creates its slave objects. When it is deleted, its slave objects are also being deleted.
    • Inhertance (is-a):

    • encapsulation: 1). data-hiding e.g. java access modifiers default, public, private, protected. 2). binding data and operation together
    • polymorphism: calling one function has same action under different contexts.
    • abstraction:
    • override: subclass override parent's method (runtime)
    • overloading: same function but different arguments (compiling time)

  2. Experiences: Composition with[out] association

    When developing a huge object, e.g. a robot object. The robot object may have wheels, batteries, vision systems and other components. Even though the robot is a single object in the real world. A simpler development method is to divided the robot class into different classes that achieve different functions, e.g. the wheel class and battery class.

    And in this case, these "slave" classes' objects should have the same cycle as the "master" robot object. So it naturally employees the Composition.

    Besides these, a futher question is that does the slave object should have a reference of the master class?

    The answer depends on the reality. Key issue is the data flow and requesting mode (active or passive).ã€€
    Thinking about a real robot. Does the real robot's vision system should activelyknow the information about robot's body or other component.?

    1. If not, then the vision system object can be an independent module without knowing anything about the robot itself.
      Passively receiving data can be achieved with parameter passing by the master class.
    2. If yes, then the vision system object should has a reference of the master object.
      Attention: i. This is also sligthly like an association relationship.
      ii. It is more coupled than the not case. To decouple the master/slave class, usually, there will be an abstract master/slave classes as the bridge.
      In reality, this means that a robot can use different vendor vision systems and different vendor batteries.

    MVC

    Goal: developing viewers and models seperately, the controller behaves like a bridge and the user's delegation.

    1. The controller object creates the models and viwer objects.
    2. The model object does not has a reference about the controller, the data passively flows from the controller to the model (the controller invokes model's methods by passing parameters).
    3. The viewer object has a reference of the controller, so the data can actively transferred from the controller to the controller.

    + model & controller: decoupled, the model don't need to know anything about the controller.

    - model & controller: not flexible, the controller has to poll the the model.

    + viewer & controller: in PC's applications, the viewer's refresh can drive the controller to send new commands.

    - viewer & controller: coupled: controller's modification will affect viewer.
